text: In the thirtieth year, on the fifth day of the fourth month, while I was among the exiles at the Kebar River, the heavens opened and I saw a divine vision.
speaker: Narrator

text: (On the fifth day of the month—it was the fifth year of King Jehoiachin’s exile—
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord’s message came to the priest Ezekiel the son of Buzi, at the Kebar River in the land of the Babylonians. The hand of the Lord came on him there.)
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, I noticed a windstorm coming from the north—an enormous cloud, with lightning flashing, such that bright light rimmed it and came from it like glowing amber from the middle of a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fire were what looked like four living beings. In their appearance they had human form,
speaker: Narrator

text: but each had four faces and four wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their legs were straight, but the soles of their feet were like calves’ feet. They gleamed like polished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had human hands under their wings on their four sides. As for the faces and wings of the four of them,
speaker: Narrator

text: their wings touched each other; they did not turn as they moved, but went straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their faces had this appearance: Each of the four had the face of a man, with the face of a lion on the right, the face of an ox on the left, and also the face of an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their wings were spread out above them; each had two wings touching the wings of one of the other beings on either side and two wings covering their bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each moved straight ahead—wherever the spirit would go, they would go, without turning as they went.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the middle of the living beings was something like burning coals of fire or like torches. It moved back and forth among the living beings. It was bright, and lightning was flashing out of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The living beings moved backward and forward as quickly as flashes of lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I looked, and I saw one wheel on the ground beside each of the four beings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The appearance of the wheels and their construction was like gleaming jasper, and all four wheels looked alike. Their structure was like a wheel within a wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they moved they would go in any of the four directions they faced without turning as they moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their rims were high and awesome, and the rims of all four wheels were full of eyes all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the living beings moved, the wheels beside them moved; when the living beings rose up from the ground, the wheels rose up too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever the spirit would go, they would go, and the wheels would rise up beside them because the spirit of the living being was in the wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the living beings moved, the wheels moved, and when they stopped moving, the wheels stopped. When they rose up from the ground, the wheels rose up from the ground; the wheels rose up beside them because the spirit of the living being was in the wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over the heads of the living beings was something like a platform, glittering awesomely like ice, stretched out over their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the platform their wings were stretched out, each toward the other. Each of the beings also had two wings covering its body.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they moved, I heard the sound of their wings—it was like the sound of rushing waters, or the voice of the Sovereign One, or the tumult of an army. When they stood still, they lowered their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then there was a voice from above the platform over their heads when they stood still.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above the platform over their heads was something like a sapphire shaped like a throne. High above on the throne was a form that appeared to be a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw an amber glow like a fire enclosed all around from his waist up. From his waist down I saw something that looked like fire. There was a brilliant light around it,
speaker: Narrator

text: like the appearance of a rainbow in the clouds after the rain. This was the appearance of the surrounding brilliant light; it looked like the glory of the Lord. When I saw it, I threw myself face down, and I heard a voice speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, stand on your feet and I will speak with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he spoke to me, a wind came into me and stood me on my feet, and I heard the one speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, I am sending you to the house of Israel, to rebellious nations who have rebelled against me; both they and their fathers have revolted against me to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people to whom I am sending you are obstinate and hard-hearted, and you must say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for them, whether they listen or not—for they are a rebellious house—they will know that a prophet has been among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, son of man, do not fear them, and do not fear their words. Even though briers and thorns surround you and you live among scorpions—do not fear their words and do not be terrified of the looks they give you, for they are a rebellious house!
speaker: Narrator

text: You must speak my words to them whether they listen or not, for they are rebellious.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, son of man, listen to what I am saying to you: Do not rebel like that rebellious house! Open your mouth and eat what I am giving you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I looked and realized a hand was stretched out to me, and in it was a written scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: He unrolled it before me, and it had writing on the front and back; written on it were laments, mourning, and woe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, eat what you see in front of you—eat this scroll—and then go and speak to the house of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I opened my mouth and he fed me the scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, feed your stomach and fill your belly with this scroll I am giving to you.” So I ate it, and it was sweet like honey in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, go to the house of Israel and speak my words to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are not being sent to a people of unintelligible speech and difficult language, but to the house of Israel—
speaker: Narrator

text: not to many peoples of unintelligible speech and difficult language, whose words you cannot understand. Surely if I had sent you to them, they would listen to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: But the house of Israel is unwilling to listen to you, because they are not willing to listen to me, for the whole house of Israel is hardheaded and hardhearted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have made your face adamant to match their faces, and your forehead hard to match their foreheads.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have made your forehead harder than flint—like diamond! Do not fear them or be terrified of the looks they give you, for they are a rebellious house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to me, “Son of man, take all my words that I speak to you to heart and listen carefully.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the exiles, to your fellow countrymen, and speak to them. Say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says,’ whether they pay attention or not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a wind lifted me up and I heard a great rumbling sound behind me as the glory of the Lord rose from its place,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sound of the living beings’ wings brushing against each other, and the sound of the wheels alongside them, a great rumbling sound.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wind lifted me up and carried me away. I went bitterly, my spirit full of fury, and the hand of the Lord rested powerfully on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I came to the exiles at Tel Abib, who lived by the Kebar River. I sat dumbfounded among them there, where they were living, for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of seven days the Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, I have appointed you a watchman for the house of Israel. Whenever you hear a word from my mouth, you must give them a warning from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I say to the wicked, ‘You will certainly die,’ and you do not warn him—you do not speak out to warn the wicked to turn from his wicked lifestyle so that he may live—that wicked person will die for his iniquity, but I will hold you accountable for his death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, if you warn the wicked and he does not turn from his wicked deed and from his wicked lifestyle, he will die for his iniquity but you will have saved your own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a righteous person turns from his righteousness and commits iniquity, and I set an obstacle before him, he will die. If you have not warned him, he will die for his sin. The righteous deeds he performed will not be considered, but I will hold you accountable for his death.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if you warn the righteous person not to sin, and he does not sin, he will certainly live because he was warned, and you will have saved your own life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The hand of the Lord rested on me there, and he said to me, “Get up, go out to the valley, and I will speak with you there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I got up and went out to the valley, and the glory of the Lord was standing there, just like the glory I had seen by the Kebar River, and I threw myself face down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a wind came into me and stood me on my feet. The Lord spoke to me and said, “Go shut yourself in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, son of man, they will put ropes on you and tie you up with them, so you cannot go out among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so that you will be silent and unable to reprove them, for they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I speak with you, I will loosen your tongue and you must say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says.’ Those who listen will listen, but the indifferent will refuse, for they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you, son of man, take a brick and set it in front of you. Inscribe a city on it—Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lay siege to it! Build siege works against it. Erect a siege ramp against it! Post soldiers outside it and station battering rams around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then for your part take an iron frying pan and set it up as an iron wall between you and the city. Set your face toward it. It is to be under siege; you are to besiege it. This is a sign for the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also for your part lie on your left side and place the iniquity of the house of Israel on it. For the number of days you lie on your side you will bear their iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have determined that the number of the years of their iniquity are to be the number of days for you—390 days. So bear the iniquity of the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you have completed these days, then lie down a second time, but on your right side, and bear the iniquity of the house of Judah 40 days—I have assigned one day for each year.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must turn your face toward the siege of Jerusalem with your arm bared and prophesy against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look here: I will tie you up with ropes, so you cannot turn from one side to the other until you complete the days of your siege.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for you, take wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and spelt, put them in a single container, and make food from them for yourself. For the same number of days that you lie on your side—390 days—you will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The food you eat will be eight ounces a day by weight; you must eat it at fixed times.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must drink water by measure, a pint and a half; you must drink it at fixed times.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must eat the food as you would a barley cake. You must bake it in front of them over a fire made with dried human excrement.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “This is how the people of Israel will eat their unclean food among the nations where I will banish them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, “Ah, Sovereign Lord, I have never been ceremonially defiled before. I have never eaten a carcass or an animal torn by wild beasts; from my youth up, unclean meat has never entered my mouth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to me, “All right then, I will substitute cow’s manure instead of human excrement. You will cook your food over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, I am about to remove the bread supply in Jerusalem. They will eat their bread ration anxiously, and they will drink their water ration in terror
speaker: Narrator

text: because they will lack bread and water. Each one will be terrified, and they will rot for their iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for you, son of man, take a sharp sword and use it as a barber’s razor. Shave off some of the hair from your head and your beard. Then take scales and divide up the hair you cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Burn a third of it in the fire inside the city when the days of your siege are completed. Take a third and slash it with a sword all around the city. Scatter a third to the wind, and I will unleash a sword behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But take a few strands of hair from those and tie them in the ends of your garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, take more of them and throw them into the fire, and burn them up. From there a fire will spread to all the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: This is Jerusalem; I placed her in the center of the nations with countries all around her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she defied my regulations and my statutes, becoming more wicked than the nations and the countries around her. Indeed, they have rejected my regulations, and they do not follow my statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because you are more arrogant than the nations around you, you have not followed my statutes and have not carried out my regulations. You have not even carried out the regulations of the nations around you!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I—even I—am against you, and I will execute judgment among you while the nations watch.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do to you what I have never done before and will never do again because of all your abominable practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, fathers will eat their sons within you, Jerusalem, and sons will eat their fathers. I will execute judgments on you, and I will scatter any survivors to the winds.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, as surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, because you defiled my sanctuary with all your detestable idols and with all your abominable practices, I will withdraw; my eye will not pity you, nor will I spare you.
speaker: Narrator

text: A third of your people will die of plague or be overcome by the famine within you. A third of your people will fall by the sword surrounding you, and a third I will scatter to the winds. I will unleash a sword behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then my anger will be fully vented; I will exhaust my rage on them, and I will be appeased. Then they will know that I, the Lord, have spoken in my jealousy when I have fully vented my rage against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will make you desolate and an object of scorn among the nations around you, in the sight of everyone who passes by.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be an object of scorn and taunting, a prime example of destruction among the nations around you when I execute judgments against you in anger and raging fury. I, the Lord, have spoken!
speaker: Narrator

text: I will shoot against them deadly, destructive arrows of famine, which I will shoot to destroy you. I will prolong a famine on you and will remove the bread supply.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send famine and wild beasts against you, and they will take your children from you. Plague and bloodshed will overwhelm you, and I will bring a sword against you. I, the Lord, have spoken!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, turn toward the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say, ‘Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Sovereign Lord! This is what the Sovereign Lord says to the mountains and the hills, to the ravines and the valleys: I am bringing a sword against you, and I will destroy your high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your altars will be ruined and your incense altars will be broken. I will throw down your slain in front of your idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will place the corpses of the people of Israel in front of their idols, and I will scatter your bones around your altars.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all your dwellings, the cities will be laid waste and the high places ruined so that your altars will be laid waste and ruined, your idols will be shattered and demolished, your incense altars will be broken down, and your works wiped out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slain will fall among you and then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But I will spare some of you. Some will escape the sword when you are scattered in foreign lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then your survivors will remember me among the nations where they are exiled. They will realize how I was crushed by their unfaithful heart that turned from me and by their eyes that lusted after their idols. They will loathe themselves because of the evil they have done and because of all their abominable practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will know that I am the Lord; my threats to bring this catastrophe on them were not empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Clap your hands, stamp your feet, and say, “Ah!” because of all the evil, abominable practices of the house of Israel, for they will fall by the sword, famine, and pestilence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one far away will die by pestilence, the one close by will fall by the sword, and whoever is left and has escaped these will die by famine. I will fully vent my rage against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord when their dead lie among their idols around their altars, on every high hill and on all the mountaintops, under every green tree and every leafy oak—the places where they have offered fragrant incense to all their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will stretch out my hand against them and make the land a desolate waste from the wilderness to Riblah, in all the places where they live. Then they will know that I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “You, son of man—this is what the Sovereign Lord says to the land of Israel: An end! The end is coming on the four corners of the land!
speaker: Narrator

text: The end is now upon you, and I will release my anger against you. I will judge you according to your behavior; I will hold you accountable for all your abominable practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: My eye will not pity you; I will not spare you. For I will hold you responsible for your behavior, and you will suffer the consequences of your abominable practices. Then you will know that I am the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: A disaster—a one-of-a-kind disaster—is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: An end comes—the end comes! It has awakened against you! Look, it is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: Doom is coming upon you who live in the land! The time is coming, the day is near. There are sounds of tumult, not shouts of joy, on the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon now I will pour out my rage on you; I will fully vent my anger against you. I will judge you according to your behavior. I will hold you accountable for all your abominable practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: My eye will not pity you; I will not spare you. For your behavior I will hold you accountable, and you will suffer the consequences of your abominable practices. Then you will know that it is I, the Lord, who is striking you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, the day! Look, it is coming! Doom has gone out! The staff has budded, pride has blossomed!
speaker: Narrator

text: Violence has grown into a staff that supports wickedness. Not one of them will be left—not from their crowd, not from their wealth, not from their prominence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time has come; the day has struck! The customer should not rejoice, nor the seller mourn; for divine wrath comes against their whole crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: The customer will no longer pay the seller while both parties are alive, for the vision against their whole crowd will not be revoked. Each person, for his iniquity, will fail to preserve his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They have blown the trumpet and everyone is ready, but no one goes to battle, because my anger is against their whole crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sword is outside; pestilence and famine are inside the house. Whoever is in the open field will die by the sword, and famine and pestilence will consume everyone in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their survivors will escape to the mountains and become like doves of the valleys ; all of them will moan—each one for his iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: All their hands will hang limp; their knees will be wet with urine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will wear sackcloth, terror will cover them; shame will be on all their faces, and all their heads will be shaved bald.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will discard their silver in the streets, and their gold will be treated like filth. Their silver and gold will not be able to deliver them on the day of the Lord’s fury. They will not satisfy their hunger or fill their stomachs because their wealth was the obstacle leading to their iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rendered the beauty of his ornaments into pride, and with it they made their abominable images—their detestable idols. Therefore I will render it filthy to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give it to foreigners as loot, to the world’s wicked ones as plunder, and they will desecrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn my face away from them, and they will desecrate my treasured place. Vandals will enter it and desecrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Make the chain, because the land is full of murder and the city is full of violence.)
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring the most wicked of the nations, and they will take possession of their houses. I will put an end to the arrogance of the strong, and their sanctuaries will be desecrated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terror is coming! They will seek peace, but find none.
speaker: Narrator

text: Disaster after disaster will come, and one rumor after another. They will seek a vision from a prophet; priestly instruction will disappear, along with counsel from the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king will mourn and the prince will be clothed with shuddering; the hands of the people of the land will tremble. Based on their behavior I will deal with them, and by their standard of justice I will judge them. Then they will know that I am the Lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the sixth year, in the sixth month, on the fifth of the month, as I was sitting in my house with the elders of Judah sitting in front of me, the hand of the Sovereign Lord seized me.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, I noticed a form that appeared to be a man. From his waist downward was something like fire, and from his waist upward something like a brightness, like an amber glow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stretched out the form of a hand and grabbed me by a lock of hair on my head. Then a wind lifted me up between the earth and sky and brought me to Jerusalem by divine visions, to the door of the inner gate that faces north where the statue that provokes to jealousy was located.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I perceived that the glory of the God of Israel was there, as in the vision I had seen earlier in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, look up toward the north.” So I looked up toward the north, and I noticed to the north of the altar gate was this statue of jealousy at the entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, do you see what they are doing—the great abominations that the people of Israel are practicing here, to drive me far from my sanctuary? But you will see greater abominations than these!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought me to the entrance of the court, and as I watched, I noticed a hole in the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, dig into the wall.” So I dug into the wall and discovered a doorway.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Go in and see the evil abominations they are practicing here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I went in and looked. I noticed every figure of creeping thing and beast—detestable images—and every idol of the house of Israel, engraved on the wall all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seventy men from the elders of the house of Israel (with Jaazaniah son of Shaphan standing among them) were standing in front of them, each with a censer in his hand, and fragrant vapors from a cloud of incense were swirling upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Do you see, son of man, what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark, each in the chamber of his idolatrous images? For they think, ‘The Lord does not see us! The Lord has abandoned the land!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “You will see them practicing even greater abominations!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me to the entrance of the north gate of the Lord’s house. I noticed women sitting there weeping for Tammuz.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Do you see this, son of man? You will see even greater abominations than these!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me to the inner court of the Lord’s house. Right there at the entrance to the Lord’s temple, between the porch and the altar, were about twenty-five men with their backs to the Lord’s temple, facing east—they were worshiping the sun toward the east!
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Do you see, son of man? Is it a trivial thing that the house of Judah commits these abominations they are practicing here? For they have filled the land with violence and provoked me to anger still further. Look, they are putting the branch to their nose!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I will act with fury! My eye will not pity them nor will I spare them. When they have shouted in my ears, I will not listen to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he shouted in my ears, “Approach, you who are to visit destruction on the city, each with his destructive weapon in his hand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next I noticed six men coming from the direction of the upper gate that faces north, each with his war club in his hand. Among them was a man dressed in linen with a writing kit at his side. They came and stood beside the bronze altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the glory of the God of Israel went up from the cherub where it had rested to the threshold of the temple. He called to the man dressed in linen who had the writing kit at his side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go through the city of Jerusalem and put a mark on the foreheads of the people who moan and groan over all the abominations practiced in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While I listened, he said to the others, “Go through the city after him and strike people down; do not let your eye pity nor spare anyone!
speaker: Narrator

text: Old men, young men, young women, little children, and women—wipe them out! But do not touch anyone who has the mark. Begin at my sanctuary!” So they began with the elders who were at the front of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Defile the temple and fill the courtyards with corpses. Go!” So they went out and struck people down throughout the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were striking them down, I was left alone, and I threw myself face down and cried out, “Ah, Sovereign Lord! Will you destroy the entire remnant of Israel when you pour out your fury on Jerusalem?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “The sin of the house of Israel and Judah is extremely great; the land is full of murder, and the city is full of corruption, for they say, ‘The Lord has abandoned the land, and the Lord does not see!’
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for me, my eye will not pity them nor will I spare them; I hereby repay them for what they have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next I noticed the man dressed in linen with the writing kit at his side bringing back word: “I have done just as you commanded me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, I saw on the platform above the top of the cherubim something like a sapphire, resembling the shape of a throne, appearing above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the man dressed in linen, “Go between the wheelwork underneath the cherubim. Fill your hands with burning coals from among the cherubim and scatter them over the city.” He went as I watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The cherubim were standing on the south side of the temple when the man went in, and a cloud filled the inner court.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the glory of the Lord arose from the cherub and moved to the threshold of the temple. The temple was filled with the cloud while the court was filled with the brightness of the Lord’s glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sound of the wings of the cherubim could be heard from the outer court, like the sound of the Sovereign God when he speaks.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord commanded the man dressed in linen, “Take fire from within the wheelwork, from among the cherubim,” the man went in and stood by one of the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the cherubim stretched out his hand toward the fire that was among the cherubim. He took some and put it into the hands of the man dressed in linen, who took it and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The cherubim appeared to have the form of human hands under their wings.)
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, I noticed four wheels by the cherubim, one wheel beside each cherub; the wheels gleamed like jasper.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for their appearance, all four of them looked the same, something like a wheel within a wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they moved, they would go in any of the four directions they faced without turning as they moved; in the direction the head would turn they would follow without turning as they moved,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with their entire bodies, their backs, their hands, and their wings. The wheels of the four of them were full of eyes all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for their wheels, they were called “the wheelwork” as I listened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the cherubim had four faces: The first was the face of a cherub, the second that of a man, the third that of a lion, and the fourth that of an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim rose up; these were the living beings I saw at the Kebar River.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cherubim moved, the wheels moved beside them; when the cherubim spread their wings to rise from the ground, the wheels did not move from their side.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cherubim stood still, the wheels stood still, and when they rose up, the wheels rose up with them, for the spirit of the living beings was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the glory of the Lord moved away from the threshold of the temple and stopped above the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim spread their wings, and they rose up from the earth while I watched (when they went, the wheels went alongside them). They stopped at the entrance to the east gate of the Lord’s temple as the glory of the God of Israel hovered above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the living creatures that I saw at the Kebar River underneath the God of Israel; I knew that they were cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each had four faces; each had four wings and the form of human hands under the wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the form of their faces, they were the faces whose appearance I had seen at the Kebar River. Each one moved straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wind lifted me up and brought me to the east gate of the Lord’s temple that faces the east. There, at the entrance of the gate, I noticed twenty-five men. Among them I saw Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah, officials of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, “Son of man, these are the men who plot evil and give wicked advice in this city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They say, ‘The time is not near to build houses; the city is a cooking pot, and we are the meat in it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, prophesy against them! Prophesy, son of man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came upon me and said to me, “Say: ‘This is what the Lord says: This is what you are thinking, O house of Israel; I know what goes through your minds.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have killed many people in this city; you have filled its streets with corpses.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: ‘The corpses you have dumped in the midst of the city are the meat, and this city is the cooking pot, but I will take you out of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You fear the sword, so the sword I will bring against you,’ declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But I will take you out of the city. And I will hand you over to foreigners. I will execute judgments on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die by the sword; I will judge you at the border of Israel. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This city will not be a cooking pot for you, and you will not be meat within it; I will judge you at the border of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, whose statutes you have not followed and whose regulations you have not carried out. Instead you have behaved according to the regulations of the nations around you!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, while I was prophesying, Pelatiah son of Benaiah died. Then I threw myself face down and cried out with a loud voice, “Alas, Sovereign Lord! You are completely wiping out the remnant of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, your brothers, your relatives, and the whole house of Israel, all of them are those to whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem have said, ‘They have gone far away from the Lord; to us this land has been given as a possession.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore say: ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Although I have removed them far away among the nations and have dispersed them among the countries, I have been a little sanctuary for them among the lands where they have gone.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore say: ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: When I regather you from the peoples and assemble you from the lands where you have been dispersed, I will give you back the country of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When they return to it, they will remove from it all its detestable things and all its abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give them one heart and I will put a new spirit within them; I will remove the hearts of stone from their bodies and I will give them tender hearts,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they may follow my statutes and observe my regulations and carry them out. Then they will be my people, and I will be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those whose hearts are devoted to detestable things and abominations, I hereby repay them for what they have done, says the Sovereign Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the cherubim spread their wings with their wheels alongside them while the glory of the God of Israel hovered above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The glory of the Lord rose up from within the city and stopped over the mountain east of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then a wind lifted me up and carried me to the exiles in Babylonia, in the vision given to me by the Spirit of God.
Then the vision I had seen went up from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I told the exiles everything the Lord had shown me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, you are living in the midst of a rebellious house. They have eyes to see, but do not see, and ears to hear, but do not hear, because they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, son of man, pack up your belongings as if for exile. During the day, while they are watching, pretend to go into exile. Go from where you live to another place. Perhaps they will understand, although they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring out your belongings packed for exile during the day while they are watching. And go out at evening, while they are watching, as if for exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they are watching, dig a hole in the wall and carry your belongings out through it.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they are watching, raise your baggage onto your shoulder and carry it out in the dark. You must cover your face so that you cannot see the ground because I have made you an object lesson to the house of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I did just as I was commanded. I carried out my belongings packed for exile during the day, and at evening I dug myself a hole through the wall with my hands. I went out in the darkness, carrying my baggage on my shoulder while they watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me in the morning:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, has not the house of Israel, that rebellious house, said to you, ‘What are you doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The prince will raise this burden in Jerusalem, and all the house of Israel within it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Say, ‘I am an object lesson for you. Just as I have done, so it will be done to them; they will go into exile and captivity.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The prince who is among them will raise his belongings onto his shoulder in darkness and will go out. He will dig a hole in the wall to leave through. He will cover his face so that he cannot see the land with his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will throw my net over him, and he will be caught in my snare. I will bring him to Babylon, the land of the Chaldeans (but he will not see it), and there he will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his retinue—his attendants and his troops—I will scatter to every wind; I will unleash a sword behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then they will know that I am the Lord when I disperse them among the nations and scatter them among foreign countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will let a small number of them survive the sword, famine, and pestilence, so that they can confess all their abominable practices to the nations where they go. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, eat your bread with trembling and drink your water with anxious shaking.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to the people of the land, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says about the inhabitants of Jerusalem and of the land of Israel: They will eat their bread with anxiety and drink their water in fright, for their land will be stripped bare of all it contains because of the violence of all who live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inhabited towns will be left in ruins, and the land will be devastated. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, what is this proverb you have in the land of Israel, ‘The days pass slowly, and every vision fails’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore tell them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I hereby end this proverb; they will not recite it in Israel any longer.’ But say to them, ‘The days are at hand when every vision will be fulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there will no longer be any false visions or flattering omens amidst the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I, the Lord, will speak. Whatever word I speak will be accomplished. It will not be delayed any longer. Indeed in your days, O rebellious house, I will speak the word and accomplish it, declares the Sovereign Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take note, son of man, the house of Israel is saying, ‘The vision that he sees is for distant days; he is prophesying about the far future.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: None of my words will be delayed any longer! The word I speak will come to pass, declares the Sovereign Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, prophesy against the prophets of Israel who are now prophesying. Say to the prophets who prophesy from their imagination: ‘Listen to the Lord’s message!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Woe to the foolish prophets who follow their own spirit but have seen nothing!
speaker: Narrator

text: Your prophets have become like jackals among the ruins, O Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not gone up in the breaks in the wall, nor repaired a wall for the house of Israel that it would stand strong in the battle on the day of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They see delusion and their omens are a lie. They say, “The Lord declares,” though the Lord has not sent them; yet they expect their word to be confirmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you not seen a false vision and announced a lying omen when you say, “The Lord declares,” although I myself never spoke?
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because you have spoken false words and forecast delusion, look, I am against you, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: My hand will be against the prophets who see delusion and announce lying omens. They will not be included in the council of my people, nor be written in the registry of the house of Israel, nor enter the land of Israel. Then you will know that I am the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is because they have led my people astray saying, “All is well,” when things are not well. When anyone builds a wall without mortar, they coat it with whitewash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the ones who coat it with whitewash that it will fall. When there is a deluge of rain, hailstones will fall and a violent wind will break out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wall has collapsed, people will ask you, “Where is the whitewash you coated it with?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Therefore this is what the Sovereign Lord says: In my rage I will make a violent wind break out. In my anger there will be a deluge of rain and hailstones in destructive fury.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will break down the wall you coated with whitewash and knock it to the ground so that its foundation is exposed. When it falls you will be destroyed beneath it, and you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will vent my rage against the wall and against those who coated it with whitewash. Then I will say to you, “The wall is no more and those who whitewashed it are no more—
speaker: Narrator

text: those prophets of Israel who would prophesy about Jerusalem and would see visions of peace for it, when there was no peace,” declares the Sovereign Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for you, son of man, turn toward the daughters of your people who are prophesying from their imagination. Prophesy against them
speaker: Narrator

text: and say ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Woe to those who sew bands on all their wrists and make headbands for heads of every size to entrap people’s lives! Will you entrap my people’s lives, yet preserve your own lives?
speaker: Narrator

text: You have profaned me among my people for handfuls of barley and scraps of bread. You have put to death people who should not die and kept alive those who should not live by your lies to my people, who listen to lies!
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Take note that I am against your wristbands with which you entrap people’s lives like birds. I will tear them from your arms and will release the people’s lives, which you hunt like birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will tear off your headbands and rescue my people from your power; they will no longer be prey in your hands. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is because you have disheartened the righteous person with lies (although I have not grieved him), and because you have encouraged the wicked person not to turn from his evil conduct and preserve his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you will no longer see false visions and practice divination. I will rescue my people from your power, and you will know that I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some men from Israel’s elders came to me and sat down in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, these men have erected their idols in their hearts and placed the obstacle leading to their iniquity right before their faces. Should I really allow them to seek me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore speak to them and say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: When anyone from the house of Israel erects his idols in his heart and sets the obstacle leading to his iniquity before his face, and then consults a prophet, I the Lord am determined to answer him personally according to the enormity of his idolatry.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do this in order to capture the hearts of the house of Israel, who have alienated themselves from me on account of all their idols.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore say to the house of Israel, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Return! Turn from your idols, and turn your faces away from your abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when anyone from the house of Israel, or the resident foreigner who lives in Israel, separates himself from me and erects his idols in his heart and sets the obstacle leading to his iniquity before his face, and then consults a prophet to seek something from me, I the Lord am determined to answer him personally.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set my face against that person and will make him an object lesson and a byword and will cut him off from among my people. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘As for the prophet, if he is made a fool by being deceived into speaking a prophetic word—I, the Lord, have made a fool of that prophet, and I will stretch out my hand against him and destroy him from among my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will bear their punishment; the punishment of the one who sought an oracle will be the same as the punishment of the prophet who gave it
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the house of Israel will no longer go astray from me, nor continue to defile themselves by all their sins. They will be my people, and I will be their God, declares the Sovereign Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, suppose a country sins against me by being unfaithful, and I stretch out my hand against it, cut off its bread supply, cause famine to come on it, and kill both people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if these three men, Noah, Daniel, and Job, were in it, they would save only their own lives by their righteousness, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose I were to send wild animals through the land and kill its children, leaving it desolate, without travelers due to the wild animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if these three men were in it, as surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, they could not save their own sons or daughters; they would save only their own lives, and the land would become desolate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Or suppose I were to bring a sword against that land and say, ‘Let a sword pass through the land,’ and I were to kill both people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if these three men were in it, as surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, they could not save their own sons or daughters—they would save only their own lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Or suppose I were to send a plague into that land and pour out my rage on it with bloodshed, killing both people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it, as surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, they could not save their own son or daughter; they would save only their own lives by their righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For this is what the Sovereign Lord says: How much worse will it be when I send my four terrible judgments—sword, famine, wild animals, and plague—to Jerusalem to kill both people and animals!
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet some survivors will be left in it, sons and daughters who will be brought out. They will come out to you, and when you see their behavior and their deeds, you will be consoled about the catastrophe I have brought on Jerusalem—for everything I brought on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will console you when you see their behavior and their deeds, because you will know that it was not without reason that I have done everything that I have done in it, declares the Sovereign Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, of all the woody branches among the trees of the forest, what happens to the wood of the vine?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can wood be taken from it to make anything useful? Or can anyone make a peg from it to hang things on?
speaker: Narrator

text: No! It is thrown in the fire for fuel; when the fire has burned up both ends of it and it is charred in the middle, will it be useful for anything?
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed! If it was not made into anything useful when it was whole, how much less can it be made into anything when the fire has burned it up and it is charred?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Like the wood of the vine is among the trees of the forest that I have provided as fuel for the fire—so I will provide the residents of Jerusalem as fuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set my face against them—although they have escaped from the fire, the fire will still consume them! Then you will know that I am the Lord, when I set my face against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the land desolate because they have acted unfaithfully, declares the Sovereign Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, confront Jerusalem with her abominable practices
speaker: Narrator

text: and say, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says to Jerusalem: Your origin and your birth were in the land of the Canaanites; your father was an Amorite and your mother a Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for your birth, on the day you were born your umbilical cord was not cut, nor were you washed in water; you were certainly not rubbed down with salt, nor wrapped with blankets.
speaker: Narrator

text: No eye took pity on you to do even one of these things for you to spare you; you were thrown out into the open field because you were detested on the day you were born.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘I passed by you and saw you kicking around helplessly in your blood. I said to you as you lay there in your blood, “Live!” I said to you as you lay there in your blood, “Live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: I made you plentiful like sprouts in a field; you grew tall and came of age so that you could wear jewelry. Your breasts had formed and your hair had grown, but you were still naked and bare.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then I passed by you and watched you, noticing that you had reached the age for love. I spread my cloak over you and covered your nakedness. I swore a solemn oath to you and entered into a marriage covenant with you, declares the Sovereign Lord, and you became mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then I bathed you in water, washed the blood off you, and anointed you with fragrant oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: I dressed you in embroidered clothing and put fine leather sandals on your feet. I wrapped you with fine linen and covered you with silk.
speaker: Narrator

text: I adorned you with jewelry. I put bracelets on your hands and a necklace around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: I put a ring in your nose, earrings on your ears, and a beautiful crown on your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were adorned with gold and silver, while your clothing was of fine linen, silk, and embroidery. You ate the finest flour, honey, and olive oil. You became extremely beautiful and attained the position of royalty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your fame spread among the nations because of your beauty; your beauty was perfect because of the splendor that I bestowed on you, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But you trusted in your beauty and capitalized on your fame by becoming a prostitute. You offered your sexual favors to every man who passed by so that your beauty became his.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took some of your clothing and made for yourself decorated high places; you engaged in prostitution on them. You went to him to become his.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also took your beautiful jewelry, made of my gold and my silver I had given to you, and made for yourself male images and engaged in prostitution with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took your embroidered clothing and used it to cover them; you offered my olive oil and my incense to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for my food that I gave you—the fine flour, olive oil, and honey I fed you—you placed it before them as a soothing aroma. That is exactly what happened, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You took your sons and your daughters whom you bore to me and you sacrificed them as food for the idols to eat. As if your prostitution was not enough,
speaker: Narrator

text: you slaughtered my children and sacrificed them to the idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: And with all your abominable practices and prostitution you did not remember the days of your youth when you were naked and bare, kicking around in your blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘After all your evil—“Woe! Woe to you!” declares the Sovereign Lord—
speaker: Narrator

text: you built yourself a chamber and put up a pavilion in every public square.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the head of every street you erected your pavilion, and you disgraced your beauty when you spread your legs to every passerby and multiplied your promiscuity.
speaker: Narrator

text: You engaged in prostitution with the Egyptians, your lustful neighbors, multiplying your promiscuity and provoking me to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: So see here, I have stretched out my hand against you and cut off your rations. I have delivered you into the power of those who hate you, the daughters of the Philistines, who were ashamed of your obscene conduct.
speaker: Narrator

text: You engaged in prostitution with the Assyrians because your desires were insatiable; you prostituted yourself with them and yet you were still not satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you multiplied your promiscuity to the land of merchants, Babylonia, but you were not satisfied there either.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘How sick is your heart, declares the Sovereign Lord, when you perform all these acts, the deeds of a bold prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you built your chamber at the head of every street and put up your pavilion in every public square, you were not like a prostitute, because you scoffed at payment.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Adulterous wife, who prefers strangers instead of her own husband!
speaker: Narrator

text: All prostitutes receive payment, but instead you give gifts to every one of your lovers. You bribe them to come to you from all around for your sexual favors!
speaker: Narrator

text: You were different from other prostitutes because no one solicited you. When you gave payment and no payment was given to you, you became the opposite!
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Therefore, you prostitute, listen to the Lord’s message!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because your lust was poured out and your nakedness was uncovered in your prostitution with your lovers, and because of all your detestable idols, and because of the blood of your children you have given to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, take note: I am about to gather all your lovers whom you enjoyed, both all those you loved and all those you hated. I will gather them against you from all around, and I will expose your nakedness to them, and they will see all your nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish you as an adulteress and murderer deserves. I will avenge your bloody deeds with furious rage.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you into their hands, and they will destroy your chambers and tear down your pavilions. They will strip you of your clothing and take your beautiful jewelry and leave you naked and bare.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will summon a mob who will stone you and hack you in pieces with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will burn down your houses and execute judgments on you in front of many women. Thus I will put a stop to your prostitution, and you will no longer give gifts to your clients.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will exhaust my rage on you, and then my fury will turn from you. I will calm down and no longer be angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Because you did not remember the days of your youth and have enraged me with all these deeds, I hereby repay you for what you have done, declares the Sovereign Lord. Have you not engaged in prostitution on top of all your other abominable practices?
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Observe—everyone who quotes proverbs will quote this proverb about you: “Like mother, like daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You are the daughter of your mother, who detested her husband and her sons, and you are the sister of your sisters, who detested their husbands and their sons. Your mother was a Hittite and your father an Amorite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your older sister was Samaria, who lived north of you with her daughters, and your younger sister, who lived south of you, was Sodom with her daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you not copied their behavior and practiced their abominable deeds? In a short time you became even more depraved in all your conduct than they were!
speaker: Narrator

text: As surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, your sister Sodom and her daughters never behaved as wickedly as you and your daughters have behaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘See here—this was the iniquity of your sister Sodom: She and her daughters had majesty, abundance of food, and enjoyed carefree ease, but they did not help the poor and needy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were haughty and practiced abominable deeds before me. Therefore, when I saw it I removed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samaria has not committed half the sins you have; you have done more abominable deeds than they did. You have made your sisters appear righteous with all the abominable things you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, bear your disgrace, because you have given your sisters reason to justify their behavior. Because the sins you have committed were more abominable than those of your sisters; they have become more righteous than you. So now, be ashamed and bear the disgrace of making your sisters appear righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘I will restore their fortunes, the fortunes of Sodom and her daughters, and the fortunes of Samaria and her daughters (along with your fortunes among them),
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may bear your disgrace and be ashamed of all you have done in consoling them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for your sisters, Sodom and her daughters will be restored to their former status, Samaria and her daughters will be restored to their former status, and you and your daughters will be restored to your former status.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your days of majesty, was not Sodom your sister a byword in your mouth,
speaker: Narrator

text: before your evil was exposed? Now you have become an object of scorn to the daughters of Aram and all those around her and to the daughters of the Philistines—those all around you who despise you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must bear your punishment for your obscene conduct and your abominable practices, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘For this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will deal with you according to what you have done when you despised your oath by breaking your covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I will remember the covenant I made with you in the days of your youth, and I will establish a lasting covenant with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember your conduct, and be ashamed when you receive your older and younger sisters. I will give them to you as daughters, but not on account of my covenant with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish my covenant with you, and then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember, be ashamed, and remain silent because of your disgrace when I make atonement for all you have done, declares the Sovereign Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, offer a riddle, and tell a parable to the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to them: ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“‘A great eagle with broad wings, long feathers,
with full plumage that was multi-hued,
came to Lebanon and took the top of the cedar.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He took one of the seedlings of the land,
placed it in a cultivated plot;
a shoot by abundant water,
like a willow he planted it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It sprouted and became a vine,
spreading low to the ground;
its branches turning toward him, its roots were under itself.
So it became a vine; it produced shoots and sent out branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘There was another great eagle
with broad wings and thick plumage.
Now this vine twisted its roots toward him
and sent its branches toward him
to be watered from the soil where it was planted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a good field, by abundant waters, it was planted
to grow branches, bear fruit, and become a beautiful vine.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Say to them: ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“‘Will it prosper?
Will he not rip out its roots
and cause its fruit to rot and wither?
All its foliage will wither.
No strong arm or large army
will be needed to pull it out by its roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Consider! It is planted, but will it prosper?
Will it not wither completely when the east wind blows on it?
Will it not wither in the soil where it sprouted?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the rebellious house of Israel: ‘Don’t you know what these things mean?’ Say: ‘See here, the king of Babylon came to Jerusalem and took her king and her officials prisoner and brought them to himself in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took one from the royal family, made a treaty with him, and put him under oath. He then took the leaders of the land
speaker: Narrator

text: so it would be a lowly kingdom that could not rise on its own but had to keep its treaty with him in order to stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this one from Israel’s royal family rebelled against the king of Babylon by sending his emissaries to Egypt to obtain horses and a large army. Will he prosper? Will the one doing these things escape? Can he break the covenant and escape?
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘As surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, surely in the city of the king who crowned him, whose oath he despised and whose covenant he broke—in the middle of Babylon he will die!
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh with his great army and mighty horde will not help him in battle, when siege ramps are erected and siege walls are built to kill many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He despised the oath by breaking the covenant. Take note—he gave his promise and did all these things. He will not escape!
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Therefore this is what the Sovereign Lord says: As surely as I live, I will certainly repay him for despising my oath and breaking my covenant!
speaker: Narrator

text: I will throw my net over him and he will be caught in my snare; I will bring him to Babylon and judge him there because of the unfaithfulness he committed against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the choice men among his troops will die by the sword, and the survivors will be scattered to every wind. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“‘I will take a sprig from the lofty top of the cedar and plant it.
I will pluck from the top one of its tender twigs;
I myself will plant it on a high and lofty mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will plant it on a high mountain of Israel,
and it will raise branches and produce fruit and become a beautiful cedar.
Every bird will live under it;
Every winged creature will live in the shade of its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the trees of the field will know that I am the Lord.
I make the high tree low; I raise up the low tree.
I make the green tree wither, and I make the dry tree sprout.
I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do it!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do you mean by quoting this proverb concerning the land of Israel:
“‘The fathers eat sour grapes,
And the children’s teeth become numb?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “As surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, you will not quote this proverb in Israel anymore!
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed! All lives are mine—the life of the father as well as the life of the son is mine. The one who sins will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man is righteous. He practices what is just and right,
speaker: Narrator

text: does not eat pagan sacrifices on the mountains or pray to the idols of the house of Israel, does not defile his neighbor’s wife, does not approach a woman for marital relations during her period,
speaker: Narrator

text: does not oppress anyone, but gives the debtor back whatever was given in pledge, does not commit robbery, but gives his bread to the hungry and clothes the naked,
speaker: Narrator

text: does not engage in usury or charge interest, but refrains from wrongdoing, promotes true justice between men,
speaker: Narrator

text: and follows my statutes and observes my regulations by carrying them out. That man is righteous; he will certainly live, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose such a man has a violent son who sheds blood and does any of these things mentioned previously
speaker: Narrator

text: (though the father did not do any of them). He eats pagan sacrifices on the mountains, defiles his neighbor’s wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: oppresses the poor and the needy, commits robbery, does not give back what was given in pledge, prays to idols, performs abominable acts,
speaker: Narrator

text: engages in usury, and charges interest. Will he live? He will not! Because he has done all these abominable deeds he will certainly die. He will bear the responsibility for his own death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose he in turn has a son who notices all the sins his father commits, considers them, and does not follow his father’s example.
speaker: Narrator

text: He does not eat pagan sacrifices on the mountains, does not pray to the idols of the house of Israel, does not defile his neighbor’s wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: does not oppress anyone or keep what has been given in pledge, does not commit robbery, gives his food to the hungry and clothes the naked,
speaker: Narrator

text: refrains from wrongdoing, does not engage in usury or charge interest, carries out my regulations, and follows my statutes. He will not die for his father’s iniquity; he will surely live.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for his father, because he practices extortion, robs his brother, and does what is not good among his people, he will die for his iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet you say, ‘Why should the son not suffer for his father’s iniquity?’ When the son does what is just and right, and observes all my statutes and carries them out, he will surely live.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who sins is the one who will die. A son will not suffer for his father’s iniquity, and a father will not suffer for his son’s iniquity; the righteous person will be judged according to his righteousness, and the wicked person according to his wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if the wicked person turns from all the sin he has committed and observes all my statutes and does what is just and right, he will surely live; he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of the sins he has committed will be held against him; because of the righteousness he has done, he will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I actually delight in the death of the wicked, declares the Sovereign Lord? Do I not prefer that he turn from his wicked conduct and live?
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if a righteous man turns away from his righteousness and practices wrongdoing according to all the abominable practices the wicked carry out, will he live? All his righteous acts will not be remembered; because of the unfaithful acts he has done and the sin he has committed, he will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet you say, ‘The Lord’s conduct is unjust!’ Hear, O house of Israel: Is my conduct unjust? Is it not your conduct that is unjust?
speaker: Narrator

text: When a righteous person turns back from his righteousness and practices wrongdoing, he will die for it; because of the wrongdoing he has done, he will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a wicked person turns from the wickedness he has committed and does what is just and right, he will preserve his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he considered and turned from all the sins he had done, he will surely live; he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the house of Israel says, ‘The Lord’s conduct is unjust!’ Is my conduct unjust, O house of Israel? Is it not your conduct that is unjust?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, I will judge each person according to his conduct, O house of Israel, declares the Sovereign Lord. Repent and turn from all your wickedness; then it will not be an obstacle leading to iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throw away all your sins you have committed and fashion yourselves a new heart and a new spirit! Why should you die, O house of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I take no delight in the death of anyone, declares the Sovereign Lord. Repent and live!
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you, sing a lament for the princes of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and say:
“‘What a lioness was your mother among the lions!
She lay among young lions; she reared her cubs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She reared one of her cubs; he became a young lion.
He learned to tear prey; he devoured people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations heard about him; he was trapped in their pit.
They brought him with hooks to the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘When she realized that she waited in vain, her hope was lost.
She took another of her cubs and made him a young lion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He walked about among the lions; he became a young lion.
He learned to tear prey; he devoured people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He broke down their strongholds and devastated their cities.
The land and everything in it was frightened at the sound of his roaring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations—the surrounding regions—attacked him.
They threw their net over him; he was caught in their pit.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“‘Your mother was like a vine in your vineyard, planted by water.
It was fruitful and full of branches because it was well-watered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its boughs were strong, fit for rulers’ scepters; it reached up into the clouds.
It stood out because of its height and its many branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it was plucked up in anger; it was thrown down to the ground.
The east wind dried up its fruit;
its strong branches broke off and withered—
a fire consumed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now it is planted in the wilderness,
in a dry and thirsty land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fire has gone out from its branch; it has consumed its shoot and its fruit.
No strong branch was left in it, nor a scepter to rule.’ 
“This is a lament song, and has become a lament song.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year, in the fifth month, on the tenth of the month, some of the elders of Israel came to seek the Lord, and they sat down in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s message came to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, speak to the elders of Israel, and tell them: ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Are you coming to seek me? As surely as I live, I will not allow you to seek me, declares the Sovereign Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you willing to pronounce judgment on them? Are you willing to pronounce judgment, son of man? Then confront them with the abominable practices of their fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and say to them:
“‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: On the day I chose Israel I swore to the descendants of the house of Jacob and made myself known to them in the land of Egypt. I swore to them, “I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I swore to bring them out of the land of Egypt to a land that I had picked out for them, a land flowing with milk and honey, the most beautiful of all lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to them, “Each of you must get rid of the detestable idols you keep before you, and do not defile yourselves with the idols of Egypt; I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they rebelled against me and refused to listen to me; no one got rid of their detestable idols, nor did they abandon the idols of Egypt. Then I decided to pour out my rage on them and fully vent my anger against them in the midst of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I acted for the sake of my reputation, so that I would not be profaned before the nations among whom they lived, before whom I revealed myself by bringing them out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘So I brought them out of the land of Egypt and led them to the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave them my statutes and revealed my regulations to them. The one who carries them out will live by them!
speaker: Narrator

text: I also gave them my Sabbaths as a reminder of our relationship, so that they would know that I, the Lord, sanctify them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the house of Israel rebelled against me in the wilderness; they did not follow my statutes and they rejected my regulations (the one who obeys them will live by them), and they utterly desecrated my Sabbaths. So I decided to pour out my rage on them in the wilderness and destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I acted for the sake of my reputation, so that I would not be profaned before the nations in whose sight I had brought them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also swore to them in the wilderness that I would not bring them to the land I had given them—a land flowing with milk and honey, the most beautiful of all lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did this because they rejected my regulations, did not follow my statutes, and desecrated my Sabbaths; for their hearts followed their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I had pity on them and did not destroy them, so I did not make an end of them in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But I said to their children in the wilderness, “Do not follow the practices of your fathers; do not observe their regulations, nor defile yourselves with their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God; follow my statutes, observe my regulations, and carry them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Treat my Sabbaths as holy and they will be a reminder of our relationship, and then you will know that I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the children rebelled against me, did not follow my statutes, did not observe my regulations by carrying them out (the one who obeys them will live by them), and desecrated my Sabbaths. I decided to pour out my rage on them and fully vent my anger against them in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I refrained from doing so and acted instead for the sake of my reputation, so that I would not be profaned before the nations in whose sight I had brought them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also swore to them in the wilderness that I would scatter them among the nations and disperse them throughout the lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did this because they did not observe my regulations, they rejected my statutes, they desecrated my Sabbaths, and their eyes were fixed on their fathers’ idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also gave them decrees that were not good and regulations by which they could not live.
speaker: Narrator

text: I declared them to be defiled because of their sacrifices—they caused all their firstborn to pass through the fire—so that I might devastate them, so that they would know that I am the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, speak to the house of Israel, son of man, and tell them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: In this way too your fathers blasphemed me when they were unfaithful to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I brought them to the land that I swore to give them, but whenever they saw any high hill or leafy tree, they offered their sacrifices there and presented the offerings that provoked me to anger. They offered their soothing aroma there and poured out their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator
