text: Then he brought me to the gate that faced toward the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw the glory of the God of Israel coming from the east; the sound was like that of rushing water, and the earth radiated his glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was like the vision I saw when he came to destroy the city, and the vision I saw by the Kebar River. I threw myself face down.
speaker: Narrator

text: The glory of the Lord came into the temple by way of the gate that faces east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a wind lifted me up and brought me to the inner court; I watched the glory of the Lord filling the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard someone speaking to me from the temple, while the man was standing beside me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me: “Son of man, this is the place of my throne and the place for the soles of my feet, where I will live among the people of Israel forever. The house of Israel will no longer profane my holy name, neither they nor their kings, by their spiritual prostitution or by the pillars of their kings set up when they die.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they placed their threshold by my threshold and their doorpost by my doorpost, with only the wall between me and them, they profaned my holy name by the abominable deeds they committed. So I consumed them in my anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now they must put away their spiritual prostitution and the pillars of their kings far from me, and then I will live among them forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for you, son of man, describe the temple to the house of Israel, so that they will be ashamed of their sins and measure the pattern.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they are ashamed of all that they have done, make known to them the design of the temple—its pattern, its exits and entrances, and its whole design—all its statutes, its entire design, and all its laws; write it all down in their sight, so that they may observe its entire design and all its statutes and do them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the law of the temple: The entire area on top of the mountain all around will be most holy. Indeed, this is the law of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And these are the measurements of the altar: Its base is 1¾ feet high and 1¾ feet wide, and its border nine inches on its edge. This is to be the height of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the base of the ground to the lower ledge is 3½ feet, and the width 1¾ feet; and from the smaller ledge to the larger ledge, 7 feet, and the width 1¾ feet;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the altar hearth, 7 feet, and from the altar hearth four horns projecting upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the altar hearth is a perfect square, 21 feet long and 21 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ledge is 24½ feet long and 24½ feet wide on four sides; the border around it is 10½ inches, and its surrounding base 1¾ feet. Its steps face east.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me: “Son of man, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: These are the statutes of the altar: On the day it is built to offer up burnt offerings on it and to sprinkle blood on it,
speaker: Narrator

text: you will give a young bull for a sin offering to the Levitical priests who are descended from Zadok, who approach me to minister to me, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will take some of its blood and place it on the four horns of the altar, on the four corners of the ledge, and on the border all around; you will purify it and make atonement for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will also take the bull for the sin offering, and it will be burned in the appointed place in the temple, outside the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the second day, you will offer a male goat without blemish for a sin offering. They will purify the altar just as they purified it with the bull.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have finished purifying it, you will offer an unblemished young bull and an unblemished ram from the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will present them before the Lord, and the priests will scatter salt on them and offer them up as a burnt offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For seven days you will provide every day a goat for a sin offering; a young bull and a ram from the flock, both without blemish, will be provided.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days they will make atonement for the altar and cleanse it, so they will consecrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prescribed period is over, on the eighth day and thereafter the priests will offer up on the altar your burnt offerings and your peace offerings; I will accept you, declares the Sovereign Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me back by way of the outer gate of the sanctuary that faces east, but it was shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me: “This gate will be shut; it will not be opened, and no one will enter by it. For the Lord, the God of Israel, has entered by it; therefore it will remain shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only the prince may sit in it to eat a sacrificial meal before the Lord; he will enter by way of the porch of the gate and will go out by the same way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me by way of the north gate to the front of the temple. As I watched, I noticed the glory of the Lord filling the Lord’s temple, and I threw myself face down.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me: “Son of man, pay attention, watch closely, and listen carefully to everything I tell you concerning all the statutes of the Lord’s house and all its laws. Pay attention to the entrances to the temple with all the exits of the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to the rebellious, to the house of Israel, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Enough of all your abominable practices, O house of Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you bring foreigners, those uncircumcised in heart and in flesh, into my sanctuary, you desecrate it—even my house—when you offer my food, the fat and the blood. You have broken my covenant by all your abominable practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not kept charge of my holy things, but you have assigned foreigners to keep charge of my sanctuary for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: No foreigner who is uncircumcised in heart and flesh among all the foreigners who are among the people of Israel will enter into my sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But the Levites who went far from me, straying off from me after their idols when Israel went astray, will be responsible for their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they will be ministers in my sanctuary, having oversight at the gates of the temple, and serving the temple. They will slaughter the burnt offerings and the sacrifices for the people, and they will stand before them to minister to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they used to minister to them before their idols and became a sinful obstacle to the house of Israel, consequently I have made a vow concerning them, declares the Sovereign Lord, that they will be responsible for their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will not come near me to serve me as priest, nor will they come near any of my holy things, the things that are most sacred. They will bear the shame of the abominable deeds they have committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I will appoint them to keep charge of the temple, all its service, and all that will be done in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But the Levitical priests, the descendants of Zadok who kept the charge of my sanctuary when the people of Israel went astray from me, will approach me to minister to me; they will stand before me to offer me the fat and the blood, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will enter my sanctuary and approach my table to minister to me; they will keep my charge.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When they enter the gates of the inner court, they must wear linen garments; they must not have any wool on them when they minister in the inner gates of the court and in the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Linen turbans will be on their heads and linen undergarments will be around their waists; they must not bind themselves with anything that causes sweat.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they go out to the outer court to the people, they must remove the garments they were ministering in and place them in the holy chambers; they must put on other garments so that they will not transmit holiness to the people with their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘They must not shave their heads nor let their hair grow long; they must only trim their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: No priest may drink wine when he enters the inner court.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not marry a widow or a divorcee, but they may marry a virgin from the house of Israel or a widow who is a priest’s widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, they will teach my people the difference between the holy and the common and show them how to distinguish between the ceremonially unclean and the clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘In a controversy they will act as judges; they will judge according to my ordinances. They will keep my laws and my statutes regarding all my appointed festivals and will observe my Sabbaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘They must not come near a dead person or they will be defiled; however, for father, mother, son, daughter, brother, or unmarried sister, they may defile themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a priest has become ceremonially clean, they must count off a period of seven days for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day he enters the sanctuary into the inner court to serve in the sanctuary, he must offer his sin offering, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This will be their inheritance: I am their inheritance, and you must give them no property in Israel; I am their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: They may eat the grain offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering, and every devoted thing in Israel will be theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first of all the firstfruits and all contributions of any kind will be for the priests; you will also give to the priest the first portion of your dough, so that a blessing may rest on your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests will not eat any bird or animal that has died a natural death or was torn to pieces by a wild animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When you allot the land as an inheritance, you will offer an allotment to the Lord, a holy portion from the land; the length will be 8¼ miles and the width 3⅓ miles. This entire area will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of this area a square 875 feet by 875 feet will be designated for the sanctuary, with 87½ feet set aside for its open space round about.
speaker: Narrator

text: From this measured area you will measure a length of 8¼ miles and a width of 3⅓ miles; in it will be the sanctuary, the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a holy portion of the land; it will be for the priests, the ministers of the sanctuary who approach the Lord to minister to him. It will be a place for their houses and a holy place for the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: An area 8¼ miles in length and 3⅓ miles in width will be for the Levites, who minister at the temple, as the place for the cities in which they will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Alongside the portion set apart as the holy allotment, you will allot for the city an area 1⅔ miles wide and 8¼ miles long; it will be for the whole house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘For the prince there will be land on both sides of the holy allotment and the allotted city, on the west side and on the east side; it will be comparable in length to one of the portions, from the west border to the east border
speaker: Narrator

text: of the land. This will be his property in Israel. My princes will no longer oppress my people, but the land will be allotted to the house of Israel according to their tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Enough, you princes of Israel! Put away violence and destruction and do what is just and right. Put an end to your evictions of my people, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must use just balances, a just dry measure (an ephah), and a just liquid measure (a bath).
speaker: Narrator

text: The dry and liquid measures will be the same: The bath will contain a tenth of a homer, and the ephah a tenth of a homer; the homer will be the standard measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shekel will be twenty gerahs. Sixty shekels will be a mina for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is the offering you must offer: a sixth of an ephah from a homer of wheat, a sixth of an ephah from a homer of barley,
speaker: Narrator

text: and as the prescribed portion of olive oil, one-tenth of a bath from each cor (which is ten baths or a homer, for ten baths make a homer);
speaker: Narrator

text: and one sheep from each flock of 200, from the watered places of Israel, for a grain offering, burnt offering, and peace offering, to make atonement for them, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of the land will contribute to this offering for the prince of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be the duty of the prince to provide the burnt offerings, the grain offering, and the drink offering at festivals, on the new moons and Sabbaths, at all the appointed feasts of the house of Israel; he will provide the sin offering, the grain offering, the burnt offering, and the peace offerings to make atonement for the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: In the first month, on the first day of the month, you must take an unblemished young bull and purify the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take some of the blood of the sin offering and place it on the doorpost of the temple, on the four corners of the ledge of the altar, and on the doorpost of the gate of the inner court.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you must do on the seventh day of the month for anyone who sins inadvertently or through ignorance; so you will make atonement for the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, you will celebrate the Passover, and for the seven days of the festival bread made without yeast will be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the prince will provide for himself and for all the people of the land a bull for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And during the seven days of the feast he will provide as a burnt offering to the Lord seven bulls and seven rams, all without blemish, on each of the seven days, and a male goat daily for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will provide as a grain offering an ephah for each bull, an ephah for each ram, and a gallon of olive oil for each ephah of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh month, on the fifteenth day of the month, at the feast, he will make the same provisions for the sin offering, burnt offering, and grain offering, and for the olive oil, for the seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The gate of the inner court that faces east will be closed six working days, but on the Sabbath day it will be opened and on the day of the new moon it will be opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince will enter by way of the porch of the gate from the outside and will stand by the doorpost of the gate. The priests will provide his burnt offering and his peace offerings, and he will bow down at the threshold of the gate and then go out. But the gate will not be closed until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of the land will bow down at the entrance of that gate before the Lord on the Sabbaths and on the new moons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The burnt offering that the prince will offer to the Lord on the Sabbath day will be six unblemished lambs and one unblemished ram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grain offering will be an ephah with the ram, and the grain offering with the lambs will be as much as he is able to give, and a gallon of olive oil with an ephah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day of the new moon he will offer an unblemished young bull and six lambs and a ram, all without blemish.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will provide a grain offering: an ephah with the bull and an ephah with the ram, and with the lambs as much as he wishes, and a gallon of olive oil with each ephah of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prince enters, he will come by way of the porch of the gate and will go out the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When the people of the land come before the Lord at the appointed feasts, whoever enters by way of the north gate to worship will go out by way of the south gate; whoever enters by way of the south gate will go out by way of the north gate. No one will return by way of the gate they entered but will go out straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they come in, the prince will come in with them, and when they go out, he will go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘At the festivals and at the appointed feasts the grain offering will be an ephah with the bull and an ephah with the ram, and with the lambs as much as one is able, and a gallon of olive oil with each ephah of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prince provides a freewill offering, a burnt offering, or peace offerings as a voluntary offering to the Lord, the gate facing east will be opened for him, and he will provide his burnt offering and his peace offerings just as he did on the Sabbath. Then he will go out, and the gate will be closed after he goes out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You will provide a lamb a year old without blemish for a burnt offering daily to the Lord; morning by morning he will provide it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will provide a grain offering with it morning by morning, a sixth of an ephah, and a third of a gallon of olive oil to moisten the choice flour, as a grain offering to the Lord; this is a perpetual statute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus they will provide the lamb, the grain offering, and the olive oil morning by morning, as a perpetual burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: If the prince should give a gift to one of his sons as his inheritance, it will belong to his sons; it is their property by inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he gives a gift from his inheritance to one of his servants, it will be his until the year of liberty; then it will revert to the prince. His inheritance will only remain with his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince will not take away any of the people’s inheritance by oppressively removing them from their property. He will give his sons an inheritance from his own possessions so that my people will not be scattered, each from his own property.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me through the entrance, which was at the side of the gate, into the holy chambers for the priests, which faced north. There I saw a place at the extreme western end.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “This is the place where the priests will boil the guilt offering and the sin offering, and where they will bake the grain offering, so that they do not bring them out to the outer court to transmit holiness to the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me out to the outer court and led me past the four corners of the court, and I noticed that in every corner of the court there was a court.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the four corners of the court were small courts, 70 feet in length and 52½ feet in width; the four were all the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a row of masonry around each of the four courts, and places for boiling offerings were made under the rows all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “These are the houses for boiling, where the ministers of the temple boil the sacrifices of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought me back to the entrance of the temple. I noticed that water was flowing from under the threshold of the temple toward the east (for the temple faced east). The water was flowing down from under the right side of the temple, from south of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He led me out by way of the north gate and brought me around the outside of the outer gate that faces toward the east; I noticed that the water was trickling out from the south side.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man went out toward the east with a measuring line in his hand, he measured 1,750 feet, and then he led me through water, which was ankle deep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again he measured 1,750 feet and led me through the water, which was now knee deep. Once more he measured 1,750 feet and led me through the water, which was waist deep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again he measured 1,750 feet, and it was a river I could not cross, for the water had risen; it was deep enough to swim in, a river that could not be crossed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to me, “Son of man, have you seen this?”
Then he led me back to the bank of the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I had returned, I noticed a vast number of trees on the banks of the river, on both sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “These waters go out toward the eastern region and flow down into the rift valley; when they enter the Dead Sea, where the sea is stagnant, the waters become fresh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every living creature that swarms where the river flows will live; there will be many fish, for these waters flow there. It will become fresh, and everything will live where the river flows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fishermen will stand beside it; from En Gedi to En Eglaim they will spread nets. They will catch many kinds of fish, like the fish of the Great Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: But its swamps and its marshes will not become fresh; they will remain salty.
speaker: Narrator

text: On both sides of the river’s banks, every kind of tree will grow for food. Their leaves will not wither nor will their fruit fail, but they will bear fruit every month, because their water source flows from the sanctuary. Their fruit will be for food and their leaves for healing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: “Here are the borders you will observe as you allot the land to the twelve tribes of Israel. (Joseph will have two portions.)
speaker: Narrator

text: You must divide it equally just as I vowed to give it to your forefathers; this land will be assigned as your inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This will be the border of the land: On the north side, from the Great Sea by way of Hethlon to the entrance of Zedad;
speaker: Narrator

text: Hamath, Berothah, Sibraim, which is between the border of Damascus and the border of Hamath, as far as Hazer Hattikon, which is on the border of Hauran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border will run from the sea to Hazar Enan, at the border of Damascus, and on the north is the border of Hamath. This is the north side.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east side, between Hauran and Damascus, and between Gilead and the land of Israel, will be the Jordan. You will measure from the border to the eastern sea. This is the east side.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the south side it will run from Tamar to the waters of Meribah Kadesh, the river, to the Great Sea. This is the south side.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the west side the Great Sea will be the boundary to a point opposite Lebo Hamath. This is the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is how you will divide this land for yourselves among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must allot it as an inheritance among yourselves and for the resident foreigners who live among you, who have fathered sons among you. You must treat them as native-born among the people of Israel; they will be allotted an inheritance with you among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In whatever tribe the resident foreigner lives, there you will give him his inheritance,” declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the names of the tribes: From the northern end beside the road of Hethlon to Lebo Hamath, as far as Hazar Enan (which is on the border of Damascus, toward the north beside Hamath), extending from the east side to the west, Dan will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Dan, from the east side to the west side, Asher will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Asher from the east side to the west side, Naphtali will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Naphtali from the east side to the west side, Manasseh will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Manasseh from the east side to the west side, Ephraim will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Ephraim from the east side to the west side, Reuben will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Reuben from the east side to the west side, Judah will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next to the border of Judah from the east side to the west side will be the allotment you must set apart. It is to be 8¼ miles wide, and the same length as one of the tribal portions, from the east side to the west side; the sanctuary will be in the middle of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The allotment you set apart to the Lord will be 8¼ miles in length and 3⅓ miles in width.
speaker: Narrator

text: These will be the allotments for the holy portion: for the priests, toward the north 8¼ miles in length, toward the west 3⅓ miles in width, toward the east 3⅓ miles in width, and toward the south 8¼ miles in length; the sanctuary of the Lord will be in the middle.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be for the priests who are set apart from the descendants of Zadok who kept my charge and did not go astray when the people of Israel strayed off, as the Levites did.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be their portion from the allotment of the land, a Most Holy Place, next to the border of the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Alongside the border of the priests, the Levites will have an allotment 8¼ miles in length and 3⅓ miles in width. The whole length will be 8¼ miles and the width 3⅓ miles.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not sell or exchange any of it; they must not transfer this choice portion of land, for it is set apart to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The remainder, 1⅔ miles in width and 8¼ miles in length, will be for common use by the city, for houses and for open space. The city will be in the middle of it;
speaker: Narrator

text: these will be its measurements: The north side will be 1½ miles, the south side 1½ miles, the east side 1½ miles, and the west side 1½ miles.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city will have open spaces: On the north there will be 437½ feet, on the south 437½ feet, on the east 437½ feet, and on the west 437½ feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remainder of the length alongside the holy allotment will be 3⅓ miles to the east and 3⅓ miles toward the west, and it will be beside the holy allotment. Its produce will be for food for the workers of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The workers of the city from all the tribes of Israel will cultivate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole allotment will be 8¼ miles square; you must set apart the holy allotment with the possession of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The rest, on both sides of the holy allotment and the property of the city, will belong to the prince. Extending from the 8¼ miles of the holy allotment to the east border, and westward from the 8¼ miles to the west border, alongside the portions, it will belong to the prince. The holy allotment and the sanctuary of the temple will be in the middle of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The property of the Levites and of the city will be in the middle of that which belongs to the prince. The portion between the border of Judah and the border of Benjamin will be for the prince.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for the rest of the tribes: From the east side to the west side, Benjamin will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Benjamin, from the east side to the west side, Simeon will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Simeon, from the east side to the west side, Issachar will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Issachar, from the east side to the west side, Zebulun will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Zebulun, from the east side to the west side, Gad will have one portion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the border of Gad, at the south side, the border will run from Tamar to the waters of Meribah Kadesh, to the Stream of Egypt, and on to the Great Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the land that you will allot to the tribes of Israel, and these are their portions, declares the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the exits of the city: On the north side, 1½ miles by measure,
speaker: Narrator

text: the gates of the city will be named for the tribes of Israel. There will be three gates to the north: one gate for Reuben, one gate for Judah, and one gate for Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east side, 1½ miles in length, there will be three gates: one gate for Joseph, one gate for Benjamin, and one gate for Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the south side, 1½ miles by measure, there will be three gates: one gate for Simeon, one gate for Issachar, and one gate for Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the west side, 1½ miles in length, there will be three gates: one gate for Gad, one gate for Asher, and one gate for Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: The circumference of the city will be 6 miles. The name of the city from that day forward will be: ‘The Lord Is There.’”
speaker: Narrator
